title: Christiane Geras
text:
Christiane Geras ("<a href="Given%20name%23Name%20at%20birth">née</a>" Berger; born 3 April 1987) is a German retired <a href="figure%20skater">figure skater</a>. She is the 2006–07 <a href="Germany">German</a> <a href="German%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">national</a> silver medalist and competed at four <a href="International%20Skating%20Union%23ISU%20Championships">ISU Figure Skating Championships</a>. Her best result was 14th at the <a href="2001%20World%20Junior%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2001 World Junior Championships</a>.
Personal life.
Christiane Geras was born in <a href="Ludwigshafen">Ludwigshafen</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. Following her <a href="Abitur">Abitur</a>, she started studying <a href="dentistry">dentistry</a> at <a href="Goethe%20University%20Frankfurt">Goethe University Frankfurt</a> in the autumn of 2006 and consequently graduated in 2011. After her graduation, she worked as a <a href="dentist">dentist</a> and instructor at Carolinum Dental University Institute at <a href="Goethe%20University%20Frankfurt">Goethe University Frankfurt</a> until her move to <a href="Canada">Canada</a> in 2018. Christiane Geras is married. She resides and practices as a <a href="dentist">dentist</a> in <a href="Cobourg">Cobourg</a>, <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>.
Skating career.
Geras started <a href="Figure%20skating">skating</a> at the age of seven. She trained in <a href="Mannheim">Mannheim</a> and represented the Mannheimer ERC.
Geras was selected to represent <a href="Germany">Germany</a> at the <a href="2001%20World%20Junior%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2001 World Junior Championships</a> in <a href="Sofia">Sofia</a>, <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>; she reached the <a href="Free%20skating">free skate</a> and finished 14th overall. She was eliminated after the qualifying round at the <a href="2002%20World%20Junior%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">2002 World Junior Championships</a> in <a href="Hamar">Hamar</a>, <a href="Norway">Norway</a>.
Geras was off the ice for half a year in 2003 due to a broken foot. She was coached by <a href="Peter%20Sczypa">Peter Sczypa</a> until 2004, when she switched to Karin Stephan. In the 2004–05 season, she won her first <a href="German%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">senior national</a> medal, bronze, and took silver the next two years. In 2007, she was sent to the <a href="2007%20European%20Figure%20Skating%20Championships">European Championships</a> in <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a>. Ranked 17th in the <a href="Short%20program%20%28figure%20skating%29">short program</a>, she qualified for the <a href="Free%20skating">free skate</a> and finished 20th overall.
Geras had to sit out the 2007–08 season due to a broken ankle that required surgery. Due to her injury, Christiane Geras had to end her professional <a href="figure%20skating">figure skating</a> career.
Competitive highlights.
"JGP: <a href="ISU%20Junior%20Grand%20Prix">Junior Grand Prix</a>"
